description: From Middle English misplesen, equivalent to mis- +â€Ž please. Compare Old French mesplaire.

verbs.description: misplease (third-person singular simple present mispleases, present participle mispleasing, simple past and past participle mispleased)

examples: Oh, i [sic] have one great Fear to misplease Him, and I pray He give me more of that Fear each Day, He my heavenly Father, not the Fear like Olga to the Knout, but to fear I misplease Him my Father, and make me not worthy of His Love.
